item.title: US Assets Rally on Bets Japan Will Curb Bond Sales: Markets Wrap
item.description: Treasuries and the dollar advanced after Japan signaled changes to its debt sale plans, fueling speculation that demand for US bonds could rise. Stock futures gained.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sujata Rao

item.title: EU Moving at Glacial Pace on Russia Sanctions says RUSI's Keatinge
item.description: For the Kremlin, outpacing sanctions is existential," says Tom Keatinge, founding Director of the Centre for Finance and Security at RUSI. "In Europe, we continue to think that we can issue sanctions that will hurt Russia, without hurting ourselves," he adds. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: UK Stocks Rally as Markets Rebound After Holiday
Merz Says Ukraine Can Strike Deep in Russia, BYD Beats Tesla in Europe | Bloomberg The Pulse 05/27
item.description:
German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said Ukraine has been given permission to use weapons supplied by its allies to launch strikes deep inside Russia. Germany had long refused to deliver the long-range Taurus cruise missile, though Merz has expressed approval of its use. In the markets, bonds rallied worldwide after Japan indicated it’s looking to stabilize its debt market after weeks of rising yields. The dollar bounced back. In corporate news, Tesla's European sales roughly halved in April to just 7,261 units, with its market share continuing to erode despite a refreshed lineup. The decline suggests Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk’s controversial politics and association with US President Donald Trump are hurting the brand’s popularity.
Today's guest: Karen Ward, JPMorgan Asset Management EMEA Chief Market Strategist, Greg Jackson, Octopus Energy CEO, Adam Posen, Peterson Institute for International Economics President (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Harmony Expands in Australia With $1 Billion MAC Copper Deal
item.description: Harmony Gold Mining Co. agreed to buy MAC Copper Ltd. for $1.03 billion, enabling the top producer of South African gold to expand its exposure to copper in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ana Monteiro, Katlego Mtshali, William Clowes

item.title: Global Bonds Rally as Japan Looks to Stabilize Its Debt Market
item.description: Global bonds rallied, with US Treasuries leading gains, on signs that Japanese authorities may adjust debt sales following a rout in the market.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Ruth Carson, Masaki Kondo

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury in Washington, DC.

item.title: US Fund Managers Put on Notice by $65 Billion Dutch Investor
item.description: Dutch pension fund PME is issuing a blanket warning to US money managers, amid concerns America’s investment industry is caving in to pressure from the Trump administration to abandon basic principles of stewardship.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: President Trump signs executive orders during a ceremony in the Oval Office following the inauguration of his second term.

item.title: HDFC Unit Is Said to Near SEBI Nod for $1.5 Billion India IPO
item.description: HDB Financial Services Ltd. is close to securing the go-ahead from India’s securities regulator for its initial public offering, according to people familiar with the plan, which would allow the shadow lender to launch one of the country’s biggest listings this year.
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty, Baiju Kalesh, Dave Sebastian

media:content.media:description: SEBI branding. Photographer: Ashish Vaishnav/Getty Images

item.title: Gold Extends Losses as Dollar Pushes Higher on Japan Debt Plan
item.description: Gold extended declines as the dollar swung to a gain and demand for haven assets cooled, with investors also weighing prospects for improving trade relations between the US and the EU.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross, Jack Ryan

item.title: Market Reforms Can Cut Bills By $120, Says UK Renewable Energy Firm
item.description: Octopus Energy Group CEO Greg Jackson says market reforms in the UK can bring bills down by about $120 per household per year. The Labour government is pushing to make the UK the first G-7 market to fully decarbonize its power system by 2030, Jackson told Bloomberg TV that this will reduce dependence on gas and ultimately cut emissions by 18%. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Top Indian Exchange’s Valuation Jumps 60% With IPO Looming
item.description: Growing hopes for a listing of the world’s biggest equity-derivatives bourse have pushed the valuation of the National Stock Exchange of India Ltd. to $58 billion in private markets, according to people involved in recent transactions.
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty, Advait Palepu, Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: The National Stock Exchange of India in Mumbai.

item.title: Corporate America Forging Ahead With Capex Plans Buoys Stocks
item.description: Wall Street’s fear that trade-war anxiety would grind corporations’ spending on machinery and real estate to a halt, so far, is looking a little overblown.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Kniazhevich, Mathieu Benhamou

item.title: HSBC Cuts Dozens of Analyst Jobs in Investment Banking Overhaul
item.description: HSBC Holdings Plc dismissed more than two dozen analysts as Europe’s largest lender embarks on one of the biggest restructurings of a Wall Street research department in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Ambereen Choudhury, Kerim Karakaya, Nicolas Parasie, Denise Wee

item.title: China Summons Top Carmakers Over ‘Zero-Mileage’ Used Vehicles
item.description: China’s Ministry of Commerce is meeting with some of the country’s biggest automakers to discuss whether the industry is using a loophole to mask weakening sales.
item.dc:creator: Linda Lew

media:content.media:description: Vehicles at a shipping terminal in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: A Classic Investment Strategy Is Under Renewed Pressure
item.description: The 60/40 stock and bond portfolio has struggled lately
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Liz Capo McCormick, Phil Serafino

item.title: JPM's Ward: Interest in Europe Has 'Further to Run'
item.description: Karen Ward, chief market strategist for EMEA at JPMorgan Asset Management, discusses ECB Chief Christine Lagarde's comments on the euro and whether it is now the common currency's time to shine. Ward also talks about investing in European markets. "Europe is stimulating in all aspects of policy," she tells Bloomberg Television. "I think we're underestimating, actually, how much growth that can unleash." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: French Inflation Eases to Lowest Rate Since 2020 on Energy
item.description: France’s inflation rate dropped further below the European Central Bank’s 2% target, reaching a more than four-year low and adding to arguments that borrowing costs can be cut further.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Metz, France. Photographer: Nicolas Leblanc/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Steadies as Traders Focus on EU Trade Talks, OPEC+ Meeting
item.description: Oil was steady as the market weighed the prospect for easing trade tensions between the European Union and the US ahead of an OPEC+ meeting on supply policy.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: A tank at the Burnaby Terminal in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, on Saturday, Feb. 24, 2024. With an expansion of the Trans Mountain crude pipeline set to start operation in the months ahead, the supply of western Canadian oil available for export is set to rise by about 500,000 barrels a day by the end of next year, S&P Global estimates. Photographer: Paige Taylor White/Bloomberg

item.title: Investors With $7 Trillion Cash on the Sidelines Await Nvidia
item.description: An upbeat earnings report by Nvidia Corp. would bode well for a rally in US equities as investors have about $7 trillion parked in cash funds, according to BBVA strategists.
item.dc:creator: Christian Dass

item.title: Charterhouse Sells Gelato Maker Casa Optima to Terlos
item.description: Charterhouse Capital Partners has agreed to sell Casa Optima, a gelato and pastry ingredient maker, to a group of investors led by consumer-focused private equity firm Terlos.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath

media:content.media:description: A sampling of gelato is served at Il Buco Alimentari e Vineria in New York, U.S., on March 5, 2012. The restaurant is located at 53 Great Jones Street in Manhattan. Photographer: Paul Goguen

item.title: Mitsui OSK Seeks Japan’s Help as EU Sanctions LNG Tankers
item.description: Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd. is seeking help from the Japanese government after a surprise decision by the European Union to sanction three of its liquefied natural gas tankers linked to a Russian project.
item.dc:creator: Reina Sasaki, Tsuyoshi Inajima

media:content.media:description: The North Moon LNG tanker. Source: MarineTraffic

item.title: Japanese Bonds Surge on Bets That Government May Tweak Issuance
item.description: Japanese government bonds rallied Tuesday on signs that the finance ministry may be prepared to adjust debt issuance following a rout in the market.
item.dc:creator: Masahiro Hidaka, Mia Glass

item.title: Cerberus Eyes Darwin Port, Australia Reviews Chinese Control
item.description: US private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management LP expressed interest in purchasing the lease for Australia’s strategically important Port of Darwin from Landbridge Group, despite the Chinese firm insisting it has no interest in selling the asset.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott, Sharon Klyne

media:content.media:description: The access entry to the Port of Darwin. Photographer: Darrian Traynor/Getty Images

item.title: Middle East’s First IPO Since Tariff Turmoil Sees Choppy Debut
item.description: Saudi packaging manufacturer United Carton Industries Co.’s stock climbed amid a mixed debut in Riyadh, a sign that broader market turbulence may be impacting Middle Eastern listings.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta

item.title: Long-End Bonds in Structural Bear Market: 3-Minute MLIV
item.description: Anna Edwards, Guy Johnson, Kriti Gupta and Mark Cudmore break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Japan’s Super-Long Bond Yields Slide on Unusual MOF Move
item.description: Japan’s super-long bond yields slid sharply after the finance ministry sounded out market participants on appropriate issuance amounts following a recent slump in the nation’s sovereign debt. In a move that was seen as unusual because of its timing and the wide group of people contacted, the Japanese ministry sent a questionnaire to participants that also asked for comments on the current market situation, said people familiar with the situation. Bloomberg’s Brian Fowler reports.

item.title: Swiss Exports to US Plummet in First Month of Trump Tariffs
item.description: Swiss exports to the US plummeted in April, showing the fallout from President Donald Trump’s tariff policy.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Foreign sales, adjusted for seasonal swings, declined 36% from March.

item.title: European Power Firms Rush to Hedge Against Acute Wind Drought
item.description: After spending about $380 billion over the past decade to nearly double wind power capacity in Europe, utilities are now turning to an obscure and little-known market to protect themselves against a prolonged bout of calm weather.
item.dc:creator: Eva Brendel

media:content.media:description: Wind turbines and electricity power lines at sunset in Zaragoza, Spain.

item.title: Zimbabwe Sees $2.6 Billion Bridge Finance Secured in 2026
item.description: Zimbabwe expects $2.6 billion in bridge finance — needed to repay debt owed to international financial institutions and regain access to capital markets — to be in place by the first quarter of next year, Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube said.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu, Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Mthuli Ncube, Zimbabwe's finance minister, during a panel session at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, Jan. 22, 2025. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 20 to 24. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: What's Zuckerberg Getting From His Shift Toward Trump?
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive officer of Meta Platforms Inc., seems to have taken actions to make the company more Trump-friendly. Since November, Zuckerberg has already had a string of postelection get-togethers with Donald Trump and made multiple trips to Mar-a-Lago in Florida. Meta also donated $1 million to the inauguration, and Zuckerberg co-hosted a black-tie reception that evening in Trump’s honor. Bloomberg's Charlie Wells discuss this and what this means for Zuckerberg and Meta. (Source: Bloomberg)
